newsitem.title: JAPAN: E.Asian Grain - Japan sees freight up, buys corn.
newsitem.headline: E.Asian Grain - Japan sees freight up, buys corn.

text.p: Japanese grain importers are expected to remain active buyers of U.S. corn this week in anticipation of a further rise in trans-Pacific freight rates, local traders said on Monday.
U.S. Gulf to Japan grain freight rates are currently quoted at above $22 a tonne, up by between two to three dollars since the end of July.
"I think freight rates have hit their bottom and now it's better to buy ahead of further rises," one corn trader said.
Japanese buyers are currently covering U.S. corn for January-March shipment and have bought up to 50 percent of their requirements, the traders said.
Tokyo dealers quoted U.S. corn premiums at about 103 U.S. cents a bushel C&F over the Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT) March futures contract.
In the oilseeds market, Japanese soybean importers have almost finished buying U.S. crop for October shipment and are waiting for the right timing to start covering for November shipment, they said.
"We've almost covered U.S. soybeans for October shipment. But we're not in a hurry to buy for November, and want to wait for the right timing," a senior soybeans trader said.
Last week one trade house bought a 30,000-tonne cargo of U.S. soybeans for November shipment, traders said.
They said they would hesitate to buy soybeans until local oil crushers and feed makers agree on soymeal sales prices for the October/December period this year.
"Domestic soymeal prices will be a key factor in negotiating soybean import prices. We can't act before they agree," another soybean trader said.
U.S. soybean premiums were quoted at up to 120 U.S. cents a bushel C&F over CBOT November futures, the traders said.
In South Korea, corn importers are expected to continue to withold purchases as they have covered their requirements up to February shipment, local traders said.
"The South Korean market will be quiet again. But if corn prices fall to around $160-$165 a tonne, they will return to the market," a Seoul-based Japanese trader said.
U.S. corn was quoted at $173 a tonne C&F South Korea, up slightly from $172 a week ago.
The trader expected corn prices to drift for a while, unless there was marked change in U.S. weather conditions which might affect the corn crop.
Local flour mills are likely to buy one cargo of U.S. wheat for shipment in November, a trader at a flour mill firm said.
EAST ASIAN GRAIN AND OILSEEDS PRICES:

Wheat, a tonne (Canada)* 54,680 54,680
Wheat, a tonne (U.S.)* 49,280 49,280
